pros: Career growth opportunities are abundant for those who seek them. My experience has been one of minimal oversight and maximum support. Using my observations on facility needs I have been able to facilitate solutions with a great team of professionals.
cons: Not unlike most of healthcare, there are challenges with staffing and retention that has at times hindered a positive experience, However, the administrative team is fully engaged in addressing and responding to this challenge.

review_title: Seeing what you do make a difference
pros: I have worked at the Whittier hospital in Westborough for many years. Every day I leave to go home I am grateful to be part of a team that sees great success with our patients. There is a core group of very skilled, knowledgeable and caring staff.
cons: Whittier is a great training opportunity for new nurses. The experience that new nurses get during the first 2 years often leads to opportunities in specialty areas at the area medical centers.

pros: As someone who works in the office sides of things, it is hands down a great place to work. The support I get from fellow co-workers and management within the building truly does help one be successful. The company also does strive to help those who want to grow with Tuition Reimbursement Programs available for ALL employees, not just nursing department staff, one just needs to ask. Which, Whittier has a great open door policy for people to ask and address their needs, which Whittier does try their best to meet.
cons: Sometimes, when you`re in your orientation, things can be "why don`t you know how to do XYZ" so, being able to advocate "I need help" is important. Also, the nursing staff is short staffed, but a lot of places are.

job_title: Certified Nursing Assistant CNA in Lakeville, MA
pros: Caring for others in need
cons: Overworked and underpaid. Always short staffed.

job_title: Human Resources Manager in Bradford, MA
pros: I have worked for this company since 1993. I started as a unit secretary on 3-11 covering both nursing units. I enjoyed my tenure here because of the flexibility, recognition and the staff. This is a privately owned company that has been owned by the same family since 1983.
cons: I do not have anything I can think of I have worked for this company for 20 years and yes there have been bumps along the way but always minor ones. This happens with any company you work for.

job_title: Nursing Unit Manager in Haverhill, MA
pros: Working at Whittier has been one of the best choices I have made, Everyone is welcoming of new staff and provides excellent learning opportunities. I have worked my way up the ladder here and loved every step of the way! Whittier has exposed me to an abundance of nursing skills and turned me into a nurse with many tools in her belt.
cons: there are cons in any place of employment, but here at Whittier I have to say I can't think of any specifics at the moment.

job_title: Clinical Nurse Liaison in Newburyport, MA
pros: Supportive management team within the facility and corporate level, Encouraged to grow within the facility and network, Team/Family oriented atmosphere
cons: Staffing is an issue country wide, but our management team is continuously working on retention of all staff, and finding creative ways to bring in new staff.

review_title: Management Leaves a lot to be Desired

cons: Staffing, pay, lack of support

pros: A good place to learn with a good rehab group

pros: I enjoyed working for Nemasket Healthcare. It is a great opportunity to make decent money while making the lives of its residents much easier. I made a lot of great relationships on the job with coworkers and residents and was able to make residents' days.
cons: Shifts were sometimes too short only lasting three hours. Some aspects of the job can be very messy but the cons are all tolerable for what the job offers.

review_title: unless your last name is Arcidi only so far you are going to get... very family oriented

cons: staffing is always a problem. DON & ADON fill into help when they can but they have responsibilities too

job_title: Certified Nursing Assistant CNA in Westborough, MA
pros: Pay is great that’s about it
cons: ALWAYS working short staffed, forget about team work because if you ask for help it’s always “sorry I’m busy”. They over work the CNAs which is why they never last long. I’ve worked the floor by myself with 19 patients and nobody offers to help unless you ask which is sad. They hire good nurses but they get trained by the lazy nurses which doesn’t help the floor AT ALL it’s a cycle of nurses getting lazy leaving everything for the CNAs to do.

pros: Nice people to work with.
cons: The work is stressful .

pros: I love the people I work with, especially my boss. It’s fairly laid back.

pros: Good place to work at

review_title: Decent if you're young and need experience
pros: Whittier was a great place to learn. I was hired very young and since I was dedicated and ready to work i felt i did very well in my time. If you put in the work and follow the rules you will be very well liked and respected.
cons: very very high turn over, almost constant turn over most don't stay for too long. Also management is very cheap. The facility I worked out is nearly in shambles and I'm sure the other facilities are on par with ours. Maintenance wise but there was only so much we could do without minor cost repairs but that money was never forked over.

review_title: scientology of the health care world
pros: there is always time to pick up
cons: They are a very disorganized organization.You can drop off/hand deliver the paper work to employee health and human resources and they constantly lose it and say they never received it. during the full 40 hour orientation one full day of the orientation is spent having the new staff to tell everyone in the public how wonderful the organization is,,mind you once you are on the floors working you can have a patient in a room falling and you are in the room across from the nurses station ylling for help and fellow co workers totally ignore yells for help.also numerous times call lights are on and fellow co-workers will ignore call lights because  that room because its not on their assignment and will carry on reading their magazines.also they will call you to come in to work even if you request days off for weddings and major life events and try to bully/harass you to come in

review_title: Terrible place to work, do not work here if you plan on staying a job, you will quit.
pros: I cannot think of any
cons: Expected to put in hours unpaid, insane and abusive management ( the more of a bully you are, the more promotions you will get),  verbal abuse, being treated like a stupid child............. I could go on and on.   I tried 3 times to work for Whittier because it is close to my house, and each time got worse.  You are not a person, but a robot who is to be treated poorly.  No flexibility, terrible and expensive benefits, and being asked to do things that you are not trained to do and do not feel comfortable doing, and being told to do it or get fired.

pros: This is the best nursing home I’ve worked for. The supervisors are amazing and I feel very supported. They also don’t mandate nursing staff which is a first for me.  I love it!
cons: With any institutionalized care, the environment can feel oppressive and the quality of life for the residents is fair at best. Staff is bogged down with a million little tasks and you can feel like you’re just pushing pills and documenting 90% of the time . I wish I made more of a difference , but there’s simply not time.

review_title: Don't even bother (unless you have no choice)
pros: You get plenty of hours, because they aren't fully staffed. The general staff is great.
cons: They expect the world and give you nothing, the pay is (beyond)  below average. Constantly recycling through workers, so it seems that no one is ever fully trained except for the handful that have been here long enough.

review_title: Quickly became clear that the bottom line was always $.
job_title: Certified Nursing Assistant in Haverhill, MA
pros: The problem with this question is... it wasn't with the company that you found any of these things. It was with your co-workers. Their values, ALWAYS work to the best of your ability to give the best level of care to the residents.
cons: It has been over 6 years since the "hands on" staff, have even gotten a cost of living raise. Administration and upper management.. different story all together. That they would take money on the backs of the people who work for them, knowingly and selfishly.. SHAMEFUL

pros: The Leadership Team is completely in touch with the business.  Professional, hard working, top notch employees.  Hard work is acknowledged, slackers are noticed.  Almost everyone gets a 2% cost of living raise each year.
cons: Rates of pay could be more competitive, and have improved significantly, especially for Nursing Assistants, since I signed on a year ago...hopefully this will continue to be the trend into the next year.

pros: you like to work in healthcare becausde you like to help people. Its close to your home and you can walk
cons: Low pay, long hours, arbitrary decisions by ownership. little training or help for new employees

review_title: A Horrible Place for a Health Care Professional to Work
pros: The only good reasons to work at Whittier Rehab would be that the job 1)  Is VERY close to home AND 2)  you can't find work anywhere else.
cons:
Management displays a complete lack of respect toward all employees, especially nurses and other health care professionals.  They have excessively restrictive HR policies for employees.  Bullying and threatening to "take you off the schedule" are routinely used to get people to attend meetings, educational training and other events.  Most hospitals will offer the previously mentioned events to health care workers at different days and times to allow for those who work off-shifts to attend.  Whittier offers them one day, at one time, and threatens you if you don't go.

When new nurses are hired, they are not told that they need to sign a 2-year contract that states if they leave before the contract expires, they need to pay the hospital $5000 dollars.  This contract is presented to them AFTER they are hired, and are in new employee orientation!  

You also need to sign a pre-dispute arbitration agreement.  This means that if you have issues with the company, like being injured on the job or harassment or being fired unfairly, you can't sue them in a court of law.  Your only option is arbitration.  (FYI: do some homework....over 90% of cases that go to arbitration are settled in favor of the employer).  Again, you don't find out about this until after you are hired and also in new employee orientation. 

Only one health care plan is offered.  It's a $4,000 deductible plan.  In order to receive full-time employer contribution to the plan, you must work 40 hours per week.  Most hospitals in this area consider 32 hours a week as eligibility for full-time employer contribution.

There are serious patient care problems related to inadequate staffing.  Sometimes nurses and nurses’ aide’s shifts are cancelled on them if management feels it isn't busy enough.  Sometimes when staff calls in sick, little or no effort is made to get replacements, even when it is busy enough.  Patients suffer for this, and it's frustrating when you don't have enough time to take care of patients in a manner that satisfies your personal standards.  They are more concerned with keeping costs down than they are concerned with patient safety and quality of care.  I have heard repeatedly that they will not pay overtime, even when it should be justified.

I could go on and on and give examples of the disrespect shown to staff, but I think what I've mentioned above should be enough to give readers a clue about what they'd be up against if they worked here.

pros: DON is a consummate professional, easy to approach, shows no favoritism. There are opportunities to gain a wide range of experience.
cons: Patient load can be overwhelming, fewer aides than needed, nurses can be very cliqueish and dismissive to those outside their circle (Charge RNs as well)

pros: None that I can think of. Pay is OK that's the only reason people go there
cons: They look for ways to get employees in trouble . They hire substandard administrative staff that look for ways of ruining employees careers. They have lost so many great employees and now can't keep the small amount of regular staff they have so most of the building is run by agency .  They are king of cover- up to make themselves look good. The state should live live there.

job_title: Corporate Financial Representative in Haverhill, MA
pros: Coworkers in the corporate office are, for the most part, excellent people. They care and they have a sense of humor.
cons: The owners are stingy and selfish. They don't even make the pretense of caring about the daily ins and outs of their employees' jobs. Printer's broken? Make it work. The software that runs payroll for every single corporate employee is ancient, glitchy, and inefficient, to say the least? New software is too expensive. The heat was broken all through winter? Wear layers.

pros:
It's a clean facility.
The staff is warm and engaging.
It was close to home.
Starting salary was low but reasonable.
cons:
Facility leadership is felt to be unsupportive and unable to provide the needed direction..
During my tenure there were many department leadership changes related to this.
Facility leadership has a difficult time accepting responsibility for poor outcomes.
